io.github.ddimitrov.nuggets

Class Exceptions

  • java.lang.Object
    • io.github.ddimitrov.nuggets.Exceptions

  • public class Exceptions
extends Object

    Entry Point Utility class providing methods for dealing with checked exceptions and huge stacktraces. Typically, you would want to import statically the family of rethrow(...) methods, and use the others through explicit class reference.

    All methods in this class are designed to be threadsafe.

    String conversion

    Every once in a while we need to format an exception without actually printing it. That is where toStackTraceString(Throwable) comes useful.

    About Checked Exceptions

    The theory says that we should either handle a checked exception by performing recovery/compensating action, or let it propagate up the stack. The problem is that often there is no sensible way to handle the exception, and while propagating sounds nice, for checked exceptions it also requires the methods at the top of the stack to declaring every checked exception that the invoked method may call. In the end, more often than not, they end up throwing Exception and not bothering with the details.

    Another popular approach is to wrap the checked exception in an unchecked one and rethrow. While that saves us the need to add a new exception to the declaration of every method up the call chain, it adds another unnecessary level of "caused by" exception, pushing the real exception further down in the log output.

    With this class, we propose a third approach - take advantage from the fact that the checked/unchecked exception difference is enforced by the Javac compiler and not by the Java VM. This means that if we could throw a checked exception from a method that does not declare it, we can cast away the "checkedness". To that end we add a set of methods facilitating the following use cases:

    • Use Case 1: Rethrowing without declaring a checked exception
    • Use Case 2: Enriching exception message with local information
    • Use Case 3: Using methods throwing checked exceptions from non-throwing lambdas
    • Use Case 4: Transforming rethrown exceptions
    • Use Case 5: Setting default transformation for rethrown exceptions

    Use Case 1: Rethrowing without declaring a checked exception

    In the most simple case we would just want to throw a checked exception as if it were unchecked. Here is example of using the rethrow(Throwable) to achieve this:

    
 FooBar quietlyCreateFooBar() {
     try {
         return new FooBar();
     } catch (Exception e) {
         Exceptions.rethrow(e);
         return null; // compiler doesn't know this line is actually unreachable, so we need return statement
     }
 }

    As the rethrow() method returns unbound generic type, it can be used as return value, regardless of the type, transforming the snippet above to the slightly shorter:

    
 FooBar quietlyCreateFooBar() {
     try {
         return new FooBar();
     } catch (Exception e) {
         return Exceptions.rethrow(e);
     }
 }

    Use Case 2: Enriching exception message with local information

    Often, when a lower application layer throws exception, there is some extra piece of information that could help in debugging the issue. The standard way of handling that is by wrapping the exception in another exception and rethrowing. We suggest a lighter alternative of using rethrow(Throwable, String) to prepend a string to the text of the original exception and rethrow as unchecked.

    
 FooBar quietlyCreateFooBar(String templateId) {
     try {
         return new FooBar(templates.get(templateId));
     } catch (Exception e) {
         String layerInfo = "TemplateId=" + templateId + ":";
         return Exceptions.rethrow(e, layerInfo);
     }
 }

    Think a bit before you choose between message enrichment and wrapping. When in doubt, use enrichment.

    Use Case 3: Using methods throwing checked exceptions from non-throwing lambdas

    Many APIs designed for Java8 lambdas make use of the java.util.function.* classes. This creates a problem when the lambda implementation throws exception. Consider the following code trying to map files to their sizes.

    Consider the streams API - a method to find all files larger than specified size would typically look as follows

    
 Collection<File> findLargerThan(Collection<File> files, long size) {
     return files.stream()
                 .filter(it -> {
                     try {
                          return Files.size(f.toPath()) > size;
                     } catch (IOException e) {
                          throw new RuntimeException(e);
                     }
                 })
                 .collect(Collectors.toList());
 }

    By using rethrow(Callable) the same can be rewritten more compactly as:

    
 Collection<File> findLargerThan(Collection<File> files, long size) {
      return files.stream()
                  .filter(it -> rethrow(() -> Files.size(it.toPath()) > size))
                  .collect(Collectors.toList());
 }

    There is another overload of rethrow(ThrowingRunnable) that will be automatically inferred if the supplied lambda does not throw exception. Consider the following example :

    
 void processFile(File f) throws Exception {
      do something exceptional...
 }
 File processSafely(File f) {
      rethrow(() -> processFile(f));
      return f;
 }

    Often, we want to return use or return a particular value if the lambda finished without exception. In the case above, we want to return f - this is accommodated by one final overload rethrow(ThrowingRunnable, Object), shaving one line and improving the readability from the previous example:

    
 File processSafely(File f) {
      return rethrow(() -> processFile(f), f);
 }

    Use Case 4: Transforming rethrown exceptions

    The ExceptionTransformerBuilder API allows us fine grained control over the exceptions we throw. Use rethrowTransformed(Throwable, boolean) to setup an ad-hoc transformation for rethrown exception.

    
 FooBar quietlyCreateFooBar() {
     try {
         return dependencyInjector.instantiate(FooBar.class);
     } catch (Exception e) {
         return rethrowTransformed(e, true) // true means we want to ignore any default transforms (rather than adding to them)
                .replaceMessage(t -> t.getMessage() + " while creating foobar") // add extra info
                .unwrapThese(InvocationTargetException, ExecutionException)     // remove unnecessary levels of indirection
                .done();
     }
 }

    Use Case 5: Setting default transformation for rethrown exceptions

    While rethrowTransformed() gives us a lot of flexibility, sometimes we just want to set and forget an exception cleaning transformation for the whole application. That is what transformOnRethrow() is about. If you configure a transformer with this method it will be applied automatically on every exception rethrown on the current thread and its children. That is, unless the application was started with <b>-D</b>nuggets.Exceptions.transform-on-rethrow=false command line parameter.

    You would usually want to call this method in the very beginning from your main method (which makes sure it would apply for all application threads). The method can be called any time and the transformation applies for the current thread and any future child threads.

    
 Exceptions.transformOnRethrow()
           .replaceStackTrace(ExceptionTransformerBuilder.FILTER_GROOVY_SYNTHETIC)
           .filterStackFramesForClass(Pattern.compile("^(java.lang.reflect|sun.reflect).*"))
           .filterStackFramesForClass(Pattern.compile("^(org.codehaus.groovy|org.gradle).*"))
           .unwrapThese(InvocationTargetException.class)
           .unwrapWhen(ex -> ex.getMessage() == null && ex.getClass().equals(RuntimeException.class))
           .done();

    The library even has a shortcut for the above, that you can apply by calling setupTransformOnRethrowDefaultConfig()

    • Method Detail

      • setupTransformOnRethrowDefaultConfig

        public static void setupTransformOnRethrowDefaultConfig()

        Configures a transformer that would be used for every rethrown exception, unless a System property nuggets.Exceptions.transform-on-rethrow is not set explicitly to false

        This method sets up reasonable defaults that may change form version to version of this library. If you need more control, use transformOnRethrow() instead.

        See Also:
        transformOnRethrow(), Use Case 5 for example usage

      • transformOnRethrow

        @NotNull
public static @NotNull ExceptionTransformerBuilder transformOnRethrow()

        Configures a transformer that would be used for every rethrown exception, unless a System property nuggets.Exceptions.transform-on-rethrow is not set explicitly to false

        The transformer is thread-local and inherited from children threads. This means that you'd better set it early in the application main thread. It is acceptable to redefine the transformer multiple times (i.e. worker threads wanting to clean up the thread-pool stack-frames)

        Keep in mind that this transformer is not automatically applied to the argument of toStackTraceString(Throwable), so one can easily dump the full stack if needed.

        If you are not sure what transformations to specify, you may want to just call setupTransformOnRethrowDefaultConfig() at application startup, which would configure reasonable defaults.

        Returns:
        a builder to configure the cleanup. Call ExceptionTransformerBuilder.done() to install.
        See Also:
        setupTransformOnRethrowDefaultConfig(), Use Case 5 for example usage

      • rethrowTransformed

        @NotNull
public static @NotNull ExceptionTransformerBuilder rethrowTransformed(@NotNull
                                                                               @NotNull Throwable t,
                                                                               boolean suppressDefaultTransform)

        Rethrows exception, but not before cleaning it up with ad-hoc specified transformation. The transformation will be applied before OR instead-of the the default transformation, depending on the value of the suppressDefaultTransform parameter.

        Parameters:
        t - an exception to format and rethrow.
        suppressDefaultTransform - if false the default transformation, specified by transformOnRethrow() will be applied AFTER the transform specified by this method. Otherwise, ONLY the this transform will be applied (the default will be suppressed).
        Returns:
        a builder that would rethrow the formatted t when the ExceptionTransformerBuilder.done() method is called.
        See Also:
        ExceptionTransformerBuilder, transformOnRethrow(), rethrow(Throwable, String), rethrow(Throwable), Use Case 4 for example usage

      • rethrow

        @Contract(pure=true)
 @Nullable
public static <T> T rethrow(@NotNull
                                                            @NotNull ThrowingRunnable throwingRunnable,
                                                            @Nullable
                                                            T returnValueOnSuccess)

        Adapter allowing to use throwing methods from void lambdas of non-throwing interfaces. Unlike rethrow(ThrowingRunnable) this overload returns a value and can be used in return statement. For usage examples, see rethrow(Callable).

        Type Parameters:
        T - inferring the return type.
        Parameters:
        throwingRunnable - typically a parameterless lambda inside a capturing lambda of the desired type
        returnValueOnSuccess - value to return if no exception is thrown.
        Returns:
        the returnValueOnSuccess if the throwingRunnable completed without throwing exception.
        Throws:
        Throwable - thrown from the throwingRunnable (undeclared)
        See Also:
        rethrow(Callable), rethrow(ThrowingRunnable), Use Case 3 for example usage

      • rethrow

        @Contract(value="_,_->fail")
public static <T> T rethrow(@NotNull
                                                         @NotNull Throwable t,
                                                         @Nullable
                                                         @Nullable String prependedReason)

        Rethrows a checked exception as unchecked, even if it is not added to the method signature. Also allows to prepend some text to the exception message (useful when we want to capture some context without wrapping the exception).

        For more examples on the usage, see rethrow(Throwable)

        Type Parameters:
        T - return type - inferred by the compiler, depending on the context expectations.
        Parameters:
        t - an exception to rethrow as unchecked.
        prependedReason - text to prepend to the exception's message
        Returns:
        dummy value, allowing this method to be used as a value of return statement.
        Throws:
        Throwable - thrown from the throwingSupplier (undeclared)
        See Also:
        Throwable.getMessage(), rethrow(Throwable), Use Case 2 for example usage

      • rethrow

        @Contract(value="_->fail")
public static <T> T rethrow(@NotNull
                                                       @NotNull Throwable t)

        Rethrows a checked exception as unchecked, even if it is not added to the method signature. Used when we don't want to recover from an exception and propagate it straight to the top-level exception handler.

        The return type is inferred, allowing us to use this method as return expression regardless of the return type and take advantage of the compiler reachability analysis.

        Type Parameters:
        T - return type - inferred by the compiler, depending on the context expectations.
        Parameters:
        t - an exception to rethrow as unchecked.
        Returns:
        dummy value, allowing this method to be used as a value of return statement.
        Throws:
        Throwable - thrown from the throwingSupplier (undeclared)
        See Also:
        rethrow(Throwable, String), Use Case 1 for example usage

      • parseStackFrame

        @NotNull
public static @NotNull StackTraceElement parseStackFrame(@NotNull
                                                                  @NotNull CharSequence text,
                                                                  int startIdx)
        Parses a stack frame from its toString() representation.
        Parameters:
        text - containing the stack frame
        startIdx - the number of bytes to skip (useful when processing exception lines)
        Returns:
        the reconstituted stack frame

      • parseStackTrace

        @NotNull
public static @NotNull Throwable parseStackTrace(@NotNull
                                                          @NotNull CharSequence text)

        Reconstructs an exception graph (including type, message, causes, suppressed, stacktraces, hierarchy-loops) from a stacktrace. Does not populate any fields beypond what is in Throwable.

        If any exception is not available on the classpath, it is replaced with MissingClassSurrogateException that outputs the same toString() and printStackTrace() as in the parsed text.

        This method assumes that the stacktrace lines are delimited using the System.lineSeparator()

        Parameters:
        text - the output of Throwable.printStackTrace()
        Returns:
        the throwable that produced the text
